entry.title: Winners revealed: National Geographic Traveller (UK) Photography Competition 2025
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Â Seeking to highlight the best in travel photography, this prestigious annual competition, celebrating its 12th year, was open to entrants from across the UK and Ireland. Photographers, both amateur and professional, submitted travel images taken during the past year in any of six categories: Landscape, People, Wildlife, Food, City life and Portfolio.Â
Pat Riddell, editor of National Geographic Traveller (UK), said: â€œOur competition goes from strength to strength, with this yearâ€™s easily one of the strongest yet. World-class photography remains at the heart of the National Geographic brand, and the winners happily sit in that category.Â
â€œCapturing everything from the dramatic landscapes of Iceland and Italy toâ€¦

entry.title: Tips for Turning Unreadable Text Into Evidence
entry.summary: Whether it's extracting names from footage, decoding social media posts, or reading distorted text in documents, Henk van Ess explains how free digital tools can take on these investigative tasks.

entry.title: Video: How religious are young Americans today?

entry.title: 9 celestial events lighting up the night sky this June
entry.summary:
Whether youâ€™re waking up early to spot Venus in the pre-dawn sky, staying up late to peep the Lagoon Nebula, or spending the whole night on the hunt for meteors, Juneâ€™s night sky has something for every stargazer. Hereâ€™s what to keep an eye out for when you look up this month.
(9 must-see night sky events to look forward to in 2025.)
On June 1, Venus will reach its farthest distance west of the sun from the perspective of Earthâ€”a point known as greatest western elongation. This is a particularly good time to get a glimpse at Earthâ€™s neighboring planet, as it wonâ€™t be drowned out by sunlight.
In some time zones, the exact timing of this event occurs on May 31, while in others, it's on June 1. But the best time to view Venus is just before dawn, when it rises in the eastern â€¦

entry.title: Need to unwind? This new travel trend adds a twist.
entry.summary:
Taking action to restore and care for nature sparks the brainâ€™s reward circuits, fostering a lasting sense of purpose and connection. Wellness-centric travel has long been popular, with numerous health studies touting the benefits of spending more time in nature. A new evolution of the trend puts wildlife at the centerâ€”responsibly.
In todayâ€™s fast-paced and tech-dominated world, people are plugged into the conveniences of modern day life, but theyâ€™re as disconnected as ever, overlooking the simple joys of nature and the wellness benefits it can offer us. You could say that the more high-tech we become, the more nature we undoubtedly need. The practice of forest bathing to cultivate relaxation and ward off the effects of stress and anxiety is well-established, but next-level nature â€¦

entry.title: These are the best stargazing sites in North America
entry.summary:
Both urban and rural areas are darkening their skies to boost astrotourism. These dark sky sanctuaries, reserves, parks, and trails invite you to immerse yourself in the wonders of our night skies. Hereâ€™s where to go.
Travelers are increasingly lifting their eyes to nighttime skies in search of impressive celestial phenomena and, perhaps, more. â€œLooking up at the night sky is sort of what makes us human,â€ says Ruskin Hartley, the executive director of DarkSky International, a nonprofit group based in Tucson, Arizona. â€œWe have done it for millennia. Every single culture has told their first stories in the stars overhead, and they found meaning in the stars. Today, the vast majority of people are robbed of that.â€
On a clear night last November, I spent over two hours in a dome aâ€¦

entry.title: Explore the UK through its family-friendly summer festivals
entry.summary:
Sewing camps and sensory gardens will be at this yearâ€™s Camp Bestival. Music festivals in the UK are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Here are this summerâ€™s family-friendly highlights.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Music festivals are doing more than ever to cater to all interests and ages. Younger audiences are often won over purely by the fact that attendance typically involves camping, glamping or pitching up in a caravan â€” an opportunity to sleep out in the wild. But the UKâ€™s best festivals also provide an endless roster of activities, workshops and experiences to help families bond and create lasting memories. From chilled countryside escapes to adrenaline-sparking coastal adventures. Here are the golden ticketsâ€¦

entry.title: The worldâ€™s plastic pollution crisis, explained
entry.summary:
Plastic trash drifts in the ocean in the Philippines. Much of the planet is swimming in discarded plastic, which is harming animal and possibly human health. Can plastic pollution be cleaned up?
Plastic pollution has become one of the most pressing environmental issues, thanks to the overwhelming rise in production of disposable plastic products.
Plastic pollution is most visible in developing Asian and African nations, where garbage collection systems are often inefficient or nonexistent. But the developed world, especially in countries with low recycling rates, also has trouble properly collecting discarded plastics.
Plastic trash has become so ubiquitous it has prompted efforts to write a global treaty negotiated by the United Nations.
Plastics made from fossil â€¦

entry.title: David Burnham-TRAC Data Reporting Fellowship
entry.summary: ProPublica is looking for a motivated early-career investigative data journalist to join our editorial team as the David Burnham-TRAC Data Reporting Fellow, specifically focused on investigating the federal bureaucracy. entry.title: Pandemics to pollution: WHO Assembly delivers landmark health decisions
entry.summary: The 78th World Health Assembly concluded Tuesday in Geneva, marking several major milestones in global health. Delegates adopted the worldâ€™s first pandemic agreement and approved a significant boost in core funding for the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war exacerbates risk of cholera and malaria: UNICEF
entry.summary: The UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) has warned of an escalating public health crisis in Sudan, as conflict and mass displacement continue to drive a surge in disease, particularly cholera and malaria.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen: UN warns against Houthi-Israel escalation, calls for dialogue
entry.summary: The United Nations has called for restraint following another wave of escalation between Houthi rebels in Yemen and Israeli forces.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN awards 2025 Mandela Prize to Brenda Reynolds and Kennedy Odede
entry.summary: An IndigenousÂ social worker from Canada and a social entrepreneur from Kenya are the laureates of the 2025 Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela Prize, the United Nations announced on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜My husband died in my armsâ€™: Russian drone attacks on Ukrainians amount to crimes against humanity, UN investigators report
entry.summary: Russian drone attacks against civilians in the Kherson region of Ukraine constitute crimes against humanity and war crimes, independent UN human rights investigators concluded in a report published on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜We are women like youâ€™: UN honours peacekeepers for work in gender empowerment
entry.summary: In early summer 2024, Squadron Leader Sharon Mwinsote Syme of Ghana ventured into sector North of Abyei, a disputed region between Sudan and South Sudan where she was deployed as a military gender advocate with the UN Interim Security Force in Abyei (UNISFA).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Top UN envoy calls on Israel to end devastating strikes, starvation of civilians
entry.summary: Gazaâ€™s population is being â€œstarved and denied the very basics,â€ while the region stands at a dangerous crossroads, the UNâ€™s Middle East peace envoy warned the Security Council Wednesday, urging immediate action to halt the violence, restore aid and advance a two-State solution before time runs out.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aid teams plead for access amid reports Gazans shot collecting food
entry.summary: In Gaza, dozens of Palestinians have been reportedly injured and shot trying to collect aid from the new US and Israeli-backed aid distribution facility operating independently of the UN.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate change: World likely to breach 1.5Â°C limit in next five years
entry.summary: Fact: 2024 was the warmest year on record â€“ but the heat is far from over. A new report from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) warns that global temperatures will likely continue rising, with an 80 per cent chance that at least one year between now and 2029 will be even hotter.

entry.title: How did this shark swim a record-breaking 4,000 miles?
entry.summary:
Bull sharks tend to be aggressive and live near shorelines, which has earned them fearsome reputations. One eight-foot-long female recently logged a record breaking 4,000-mile journey. Along her migration from Mozambique to Nigeria, the eight-foot-long female would have encountered a zone of water too cold to cross that has kept Africa's bull shark populations separated for 55,000 years.
When Turawa Hakeem caught a bull shark near Lagos, Nigeria last summer, the Ghanaian captain had no idea his crew was reeling a record winner onto his wooden fishing boat.
The eight-foot-long female had made an epic journey of at least 4,500 miles, the longest known movement of its species and the first time a bull shark was documented swimming through two oceans. The shark traveled from the Mâ€¦

entry.title: Frozen shoulder is a real conditionâ€”and it mostly affects women
entry.summary:
Frozen shoulder is straightforwardâ€”the condition means stiffness and difficulty in raising the arm. It can be caused by partial tears in the shoulder's tendon, as represented in this MRI scan. The painful affliction known as adhesive capsulitis can last for yearsâ€”but has long been ignored by medical researchers who doubted its existence. New treatments may finally promise a cure.
Stirrups, Pap smears, prenatal checks: At her busy office at Duke Womenâ€™s Health in Durham, NC, OB-GYNÂ Anne Fordâ€™s work with female patients of all ages usually takes place from the waist down.
But Ford has noticed that a subset of her patientsâ€”all women entering or past menopauseâ€”come to their appointments with a seemingly non-gynecological issue: adhesive capsulitis or â€œfrozen shoulder,â€ a poorly unâ€¦

entry.title: These intimate safari camps offer a peek into Maasai culture
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œSimba!â€ The urgent whisper â€” â€˜lionâ€™ in Swahili â€” comes from Julius Naurori as he stands bolt upright in the back of our 4WD like a human antenna.
Immediately, our guide in the front slows the car to a cautious prowl and a hush descends, save for the tinkling silver discs tied to Juliusâ€™s waist as they sway in time with the rocking of the car. The dawn sky is still blushing crimson, and at first itâ€™s hard to see whatâ€™s almost directly in front of us: four sleeping lions, their chocolate manes camouflaged as they lie on their sides in long, unruly grass marking the banks of the Mara River.
Our guide is Roca River Camp co-owner Ross Withey, and Julius, our wildlife-spotter, is his wingman on this safari drive inâ€¦

entry.title: These remote desert oases are Egyptâ€™s hidden gems
entry.summary:
Siwa Oasis, a 12-hour drive from Cairo, is worth the trip to swim and float in hundreds of salt lakes and natural hot springs. Most visitors never experience the natural masterpieces that lie off the tourist trailâ€”from bubbling hot springs to unearthly landscapes of dead volcanoes to the â€œValley of the Whales.â€
The world knows Egypt for the Pyramids of Giza and cosmopolitan Cairo, the tourist-trodden temples of Luxor, and Red Sea resort towns. These coastal and Nile River Valley destinations are a narrow view of a country thatâ€™s 90 percent desert.
Few travelers venture into that 90 percent. The vast Western Desert, which blends into Libya and beyond, is Egyptâ€™s great unknown. Adventurers since Alexander the Great have braved the harsh clime and been rewarded with the untouchedâ€¦

entry.title: UN aims to transform urgency into action at Nice Ocean Conference
entry.summary: Countries are uniting in the French city of Nice next month to save the marine environment.

entry.summary: The Golden Triangle â€“ the remote, jungle-covered border region where Thailand, Myanmar, and the Lao Peopleâ€™s Democratic Republic meet â€“ has seen an exponential surge in the illicit manufacture and trafficking of synthetic drugs.

entry.summary: The UN International Organization for Migration (IOM) has welcomed recent decisions by the United States, the United Kingdom and the European Union to ease sanctions against Syria.

entry.title: Sudan conflict triggers regional health crisis, warns WHO
entry.summary: As the war between rival militaries in Sudan continues, the World Health Organization (WHO) has raised alarm over the escalating health emergency, driven by ongoing violence, mass displacement, collapsing health systems and poor conditions inside refugee camps.

entry.summary: A seasoned diplomat and legal scholar from Jordan was elected on Tuesday to serve as a judge at the International Court of Justice (ICJ), the United Nationsâ€™ principal judicial body.

entry.title: Real cost of disasters is 10 times higher than previously thought, says UN
entry.summary: As countries face increasingly steep bills from natural hazards, the true cost of disasters is actually 10 times higher than previously estimated, with far-reaching effects across healthcare, housing, education and employment.

entry.title: A cure for individualism

entry.title: 8 of the best beach cities in Spain
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
High-spirited northern surf hubs, relaxed Mediterranean-fronting neighbourhoods and glowing sands washed by the thundering Atlantic â€” mainland Spainâ€™s cities can offer all of this and more. Take your pick of these varied urban beauties, scattered around the countryâ€™s 3,000-mile peninsular coast. Beaches in Spain can get packed everywhere during the high season, from July to August, so for the best chance of solitude and space, itâ€™s worth travelling in the quieter shoulder periods.
A pair of wide gold beaches, tucked into a crescent-moon bay between forested headlands, sets the scene for one of northern Spainâ€™s most popular coastal escapes. Many San SebastiÃ¡n strolls begin on the promenade curving past Playa de Onâ€¦

entry.title: Are airline loyalty schemes worth it?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
When British Airways (BA) launched its revamped frequent-flyer scheme on 1 April, it probably didnâ€™t anticipate the furore that would follow. The new logo and name change â€” a contraction from the Executive Club to simply the Club â€” were uncontroversial. Instead, the outcry concerned the airline changing the way it plans to reward its customers.
Like most airline loyalty schemes, BA rewards its customers with two sets of points. The first, reward points â€”Â known as Avios in BAâ€™s case â€” are essentially an airline currency, and you can save these over months or years and redeem them for cheap flights and upgrades. The second, loyalty points, which BA calls Tier points, are collected over a single year and will move youâ€¦

entry.title: UN warns of â€˜catastrophicâ€™ human rights crisis in Myanmar as violence and economic collapse deepen
entry.summary: Myanmarâ€™s spiralling human rights crisis â€“ fuelled by relentless military violence, systemic impunity and economic collapse â€“ has left civilians caught in the crossfire of an increasingly brutal conflict, according to a new report by the UN human rights office (OHCHR).

entry.title: UN rights chief calls for end to daily killings in Ukraine after deadly weekend attacks
entry.summary: The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has called for an immediate end to the daily killings and destruction in Ukraine, following a weekend of deadly attacks that left at least 14 civilians â€“ including three children â€“ dead and dozens more injured across the country.

entry.title: Top marks for Lebanon schools project helping marginalised kids
entry.summary: An inclusive education programme in Lebanon is getting top marks from teachers and students, especially children with disabilities who are often the most marginalised.

entry.title: Whatâ€™s your poison? Alcohol linked to higher risk of pancreatic cancer
entry.summary: Alcoholic drinks, especially beer and spirits, may raise the risk of pancreatic cancer, a new UN study has found.

entry.title: Gazansâ€™ suffering goes on amid intensifying Israeli strikes
entry.summary: After another deadly weekend of Israeli attacks in Gaza, aid teams stressed once again on Monday that the â€œtrickleâ€ of supplies being allowed into the war-torn enclave will not halt famine.

entry.title: UN rights mission deplores deadly Russian strikes in Ukraine
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) has deplored a deadly wave of Russian missile and drone strikes that reportedly killed at least 13 civilians and injured 65 others, warning that the attack underscores the grave risks of using powerful explosive weapons in populated areas.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Explore New Zealand one scenic drive at a time
entry.summary:
Life moves at a slower pace in New Zealand so taking your time while hitting the wide-open road is the best way to experience it. Starting from the countryâ€™s main gateways, such as Auckland and Christchurch, these road trips offer the best chance to experience the wealth and breadth of New Zealandâ€™s unparalleled landscapes.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
In Aotearoa (the MÄori name for New Zealand, which is often translated as â€˜the land of the long white cloudâ€™), life moves at a slower pace so taking your time while hitting the wide-open road is the best way to experience it. Meander through mountain ranges and past pancake rocks to wineries and whale-watching spots on New Zealandâ€™s wild South Island, while on the North Island, take a leisurâ€¦

entry.title: Is Sasquatch real? Some Harrison Hot Springs residents say yes
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Henry Williams wasnâ€™t always a believer in the Sasquatch. Growing up, he had of course heard the tales of old â€” of a legendary hairy, bipedal primate said to roam the forests at sundown. Yet for much of his life, 76-year-old Henry had shrugged these stories off without much thought. They were used to remind youngsters to come home before nightfall, heâ€™d reasoned. All that changed, however, on the day that the Sasquatch came to pay him a visit two decades ago, near his home in Squamish in southwest British Columbia.
â€œIt threw a huge boulder into the middle of a nearby river,â€ says Henry, flinging his arms wide to imitate an almighty splash as we chat in the lobby of the Harrison Hot Springs Resort, a historic hotel â€¦

entry.title: Thousands flee homes in Mozambique as conflict and disasters fuel worsening crisis
entry.summary: More than 25,000 people have been forced to flee their homes in northern Mozambique in recent weeks, as conflict and a series of disasters fuel a worsening humanitarian crisis â€“ one that risks deepening as vital relief operations face a severe funding shortfall.

entry.title: 6 of the best rail adventures in British Columbia
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
British Columbia, Canadaâ€™s westernmost province, is well known for its spectacular landscapes, offering endless views of serrated peaks, opaline glacier lakes and feather-tipped pines. And what better way to take it all in than on a train, with those big-picture vistas slowly rolling by beyond the windowpanes â€” here are some of the best rail routes to try.
Vancouver to Banff; 2 days This double-decker train is surely one of the worldâ€™s most scenic rail journeys, offering bubble-domed vistas of mountains, lakes, forests, gorges, rivers and glaciers and the chance to spot wildlife along the way. The classic First Passage to the West route follows part of the line from the historic Canadian Pacific Railway, Canadaâ€™sâ€¦

entry.title: Where to find Ireland's best food? Head west.
entry.summary:
Across County Corkâ€™s wide and quiet expanse of gently rolling hills and craggy coastline, a culinary renaissance is unfolding, led by dairy farmers, foragers, fish smokers, and chefs. Here, Irelandâ€™s soul and story are best understood on the plate.
Long overlooked on Europeâ€™s gastronomic map, Ireland is emerging as a top culinary destinationâ€”nowhere more so than in this rugged southwestern corner. County Cork's unique microclimate and creative community has served as fertile ground for culinary invention; and the hills are green nearly all year and shores are laden with seaweed superfoods. Youâ€™ll find Michelin-starred restaurants hiding in villages of just a few hundred people, farmers crafting new kinds of cheese, and wild foragers bringing the native plants of Ireland back to palateâ€¦

entry.title: Why some people are better off sleeping on their sides
entry.summary:
If you struggle with sleep apnea, acid reflux, or back pain, changing how you sleep may offer some relief. Your sleep position can cause everything from back pain to acid reflux. A simple change can improve your health dramatically.
In recent years, a preponderance of research has shown that something as simple as sleeping on your side may be the answer to reducing back pain, heartburn, and sleep apneaâ€”conditions that affect tens of millions of peopleâ€”even if it doesnâ€™t also provide relief to some other issues people think it does.
â€œSide sleeping does have clear benefits over stomach or back sleeping, but only for certain groups of individuals,"Â says Raj Dasgupta, a pulmonary and sleep medicine physician at Huntington Memorial Hospital in California.
Here's what to know â€¦

entry.title: See Lake Como and the Italian Riviera without the crowds
entry.summary: Travelers looking for la dolce vita or the sweet life in Italy should consider a visit to the picturesque town of Menaggio on Lake Como. The three uniquely different towns of Rapallo, Varenna, and Menaggio offer elegant views, food tours and everything you need for your dream vacation. Most world travelers are familiar with the popular and often over-touristed cities in Italy such as Rome, Florence, Milan, and Naples, but there are lesser-known locales found on the Italian Riviera and in the Lake Como area that offer equally authentic experiences in Italian food, art, and cultural history. Hereâ€™s how to plan your dream Italian holiday to three towns in Northwest Italyâ€”without the crowds. Situated on the coast of the Ligurian Sea just south of Genoa and north of Cinqueâ€¦

entry.title: Quebec City offers the charm of Paris without the crowds
entry.summary:
Craving the romance of Paris without the jet lag or legions of other people? The City of Light welcomed nearly 30 million visitors in 2023, and even more admirers plan to travel there since the 2024 Summer Olympics and reopening of the Cathedral of Notre Dame. Canadaâ€™s QuÃ©bec City, a UNESCO World Heritage Site with French roots, emanates European elegance yet welcomes about a fractionÂ of the visitors as Paris. Flights from the United States clock much shorter times too, providing travelers with Old World charm minus the travel fatigue. Â
French, British, and North American cultures weave together in this walkable, refined city. â€œQuÃ©bec City is French-speaking, but itâ€™s North American, and itâ€™s unique,â€ says David Mendel, an author and historian who has lived in Paris and has also resiâ€¦

entry.title: See Sally Rideâ€™s boundary-breaking life in photos
entry.summary:
When pioneering female astronaut Sally Ride died of pancreatic cancer in 2012, a single line in her obituary told the story a lifetime of press coverage and fame had never revealed: her 27-year partnership with another woman, Tam Oâ€™Shaughnessy.
The revelation that Ride was a member of the LGBTQ+ community added another first to her lengthy list of historic accomplishments. She was not just the first American woman to go to spaceâ€”41 years ago on June 18, 1983â€”but the first known queer astronaut.
The revelation added a new dimension to the intense, brilliant physicist, loyal crew member, and passionate science education advocate. And it led some to question what Rideâ€™s life may have been like in a less homophobic, sexist world. Rideâ€™s private journey is uncovered in the award-winniâ€¦

Appendix: AI keywords used in this study
entry.summary: A webpage was classified as containing an AI mention if it had at least one of the following keywords. These keywords were detected using regular expression matching, included common variants and were not case sensitive, unless noted otherwise. The post Appendix: AI keywords used in this study appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The findings in this report are based on an analysis of the browsing behaviors of 900 U.S. adults who are members of the KnowledgePanel Digital online panel, a subset of Ipsosâ€™ KnowledgePanel. These panelists qualified for the study because they: After the March monitoring period, panelistsâ€™ web browsing activity logs were delivered on April 7, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Primary researchers Athena Chapekis, Computational Social Science AnalystAnna Lieb, Computational Social Science AssistantSono Shah, Associate Director, Data LabsAaron Smith, Director, Data Labs Research team Regina Widjaya, Computational Social ScientistGalen Stocking, Senior Computational Social ScientistBrian Broderick, Former Senior Data EngineerGonzalo [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: What Web Browsing Data Tells Us About How AI Appears Online
entry.summary: One month of web browsing data shows most respondents visited a search page with an AI-generated summary, but visits to in-depth content about AI were much rarer. The post What Web Browsing Data Tells Us About How AI Appears Online appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Why cancer rates are rising in young womenâ€”and what to do about it
entry.summary:
A PET scan of a female patient with breast cancer, which has spread to the lymph nodes, bones and liver. A recent report found that women account for two-thirds of all cancers diagnosed in people under 50. But it's not all bad news.
In its recent annual report, the American Cancer Society shared some striking news: Cancer is turning up more frequently in young people â€“ especially in young women.Â
Before we panic: The trend is not entirely a new one. Women have long had higher cancer rates than men in younger age groups. And thereâ€™s good news in the report too, says Otis Brawley, an oncologist and epidemiology professor at Johns Hopkins Universityâ€™s Bloomberg School of Public Health. Namely, it found that, overall, cancer deaths have been trending downward.
But the reportâ€¦

entry.title: Been to Barcelona? Now try Spain's lesser-known cities
entry.summary:
Stay a few days to roam the sloping AlbaicÃ­n district, where locals and visitors gather on broad terraces to catch views across terracotta rooftops to the Alhambra, backed by the spectacular Sierra Nevada mountains. Watch flamenco, roam medieval streets and find local tapas haunts in these destination dupes.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With Spain receiving record-breaking numbers of international visitors in the past two years â€” up to 94 million last year â€” it pays to hunt out its quiet corners. And there are plenty of areas where travellers have yet to claim a stake. While major Spanish cities like Barcelona, Madrid and Seville justifiably receive millions of visitors a year, the country is packed with dozens of disarmingly beautiful andâ€¦

entry.title: Why Tateyama Kurobe route is Japanâ€™s ultimate mountain journey
entry.summary:
The journey on Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route involves travelling by train, bus, funicular, cable car and even a short stretch on foot. This multimodal route through the countryâ€™s Northern Alps is a great alternative to the similar journey around Mount Fuji â€” and one which attracts far fewer visitors.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
For travellers looking to explore the peaks of Japan, it doesnâ€™t get much better than the Tateyama Kurobe Alpine Route, an extraordinary expedition through the countryâ€™s Northern Alps in the centre of the main island of Honshu. Like a similar but far more travelled route around Mount Fuji to the south,Â this itinerary incorporates multiple forms of transport â€” a train, funicular, highland bus, cable car and electric â€¦

entry.title: How one young pharaoh turned Egypt into a superpower
entry.summary:
The death of Queen Hatshepsut opened the door to rebellion in the Levant. After 22 years in power, she disappeared from history and Thutmose III occupied the throne of Egypt alone. A coalition of Canaanite city-states, supported by the Mitanni Empire and rulers of Kadesh, began to rebel against the new pharaoh. It would come to a head in the walled city of Megiddo, in what today is Israel. Sited on the Plain of Esdraelon, the city could control two trade routes of special interest: one connecting with the coastline and the other leading north to Kadesh. As this was Thutmoseâ€™s first military campaign, the pressure on him was considerable.
According to the large propaganda inscription on the walls of Akh Menu (the Temple of Thutmose III at Karnak), the young pharaoh gathered his mâ€¦

entry.summary: The UN refugee agency (UNHCR) on Friday released aÂ statement expressing grave concern over reports that two boats carrying Rohingya refugees sank off the coast of Myanmar earlier this month, with an estimated 427 people dead.

entry.title: Diplomats prepare ground for June conference on two-State solution for Israel and Palestine
entry.summary: Diplomats convened at UN Headquarters in New York on Friday to lay the groundwork for a crucial international conference in June, aimed at advancing global efforts towards achieving a two-State solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict.

entry.title: Escalating violence drives food crisis across eastern DR Congo, warns WFP
entry.summary: As violence intensifies in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), the World Food Programme (WFP)Â warned Friday that food insecurity is worsening both within the country and in neighbouring States, where 140,000 Congolese have fled since January.

entry.title: UN rights chief calls on South Sudanâ€™s warring parties to end renewed fighting
entry.summary: The UN on Friday warned of further deterioration in the human rights situation in South Sudan amid an uptick in hostilities, arbitrary arrests and hate speech since February.

entry.title: Guterres calls on Israel to accept UNâ€™s â€˜detailed, principledâ€™ aid plan for Gaza
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General on Friday outlined a five-stage plan to provide lifesaving aid to the stricken population of Gaza, making clear the organization will not take part in any scheme that fails to respect international law or basic humanitarian principles.

entry.title: Syrians face staggering needs amid insecurity and healthcare crisis
entry.summary: Millions of people in Syria continue to face mortal danger from unexploded munitions, disease and malnutrition and more international support is urgently required, senior UN aid officials said on Friday.

entry.title: Aid teams highlight growing anxiety in Gaza after food is looted
entry.summary: Long-awaited food supplies have been looted in Gaza overnight while being transported to desperate communities in the war-torn enclave, UN aid teams reported on Friday.

entry.title: In search of â€˜fjakaâ€™â€”the Croatian art of doing nothing
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This story begins â€” as many good yarns do â€” in a bar. Specifically, Beach Bar Dodo beside Dubrovnikâ€™s seafront, where Iâ€™m sipping beer with a friend. David Farley had sub-let his perfectly nice flat in New York to decamp to Croatia. Whatâ€™s he doing with his days, I ask. Not much, he replies: â€œPerfecting my fjaka.â€
Fjaka, pronounced â€˜fee-akaâ€™, could only have come from a land of sunbaked islands. It is, David explains, no place to go, no place to be. Allowing days to drift and blur. Back in the capital, Zagreb, they make rude jokes about Dalmatians as donkeys, but that misses the point entirely. With fjaka, the region has elevated easy living into an artform.
With no better plans, I decide to embark on a quixotâ€¦

entry.title: Going to the beach is good for your brain, according to science
entry.summary:
There's little more relaxing than spending time at the beachâ€”but what's going on in your brain during a day spent playing in the waves? Scientists are discovering more of the benefits of "blue spaces" like the coast. Visiting the coast can help you relieve stress and get more activeâ€”and it may even change the way you cope with pain.
The coast has long been a place of healing. In 18th-century Europe, doctors prescribed beach time for ailments ranging from tuberculosis to leprosy. Patients spent their days bathing in (and often drinking) mineral-rich sea water, and at night, they fell asleep to the sounds of briny winds and crashing waves.
While elements of this early sea therapy have since been disproven, modern science continues to find that nature is good for us. Researchers â€¦

entry.title: Do dolphins have a language? Scientists are finding new clues.
entry.summary:
Bottlenose dolphins living near Sarasota, Florida have been observed making consistently structured whistles that suggest a common meaning. â€œIf there is a species that we might be able to engage with in some kind of two-way communication, these guys are really good candidates.â€
Dolphins are some of the most vocal animals in our oceans. Their pods are a bustling soundscape of clicks, whistles, and buzzy pulses. What to our ears is a creaking door or a melodic pop is to a dolphin a means to echolocate or communicate.
They even have namesâ€”research has found they use â€˜signature whistlesâ€™ to identify themselves, a sort of vocal version of a humanâ€™s signature. These whistles are produced by one individual and repeated by anotherâ€”â€œJeff, Jeffâ€â€”to initiate or re-establish contact. The â€¦

entry.title: Take this Salvador DalÃ­-inspired road trip through Spain
entry.summary:
Travelers who embark on a road trip to three Salvador DalÃ­-related museums will see the famous surrealist artistâ€™s outdoor sculptures like this one in Port Lligat, Spain. Explore the life and work of the famed surrealist on an immersive trip to the three towns that make up the DalÃ­ Triangle in Spainâ€™s Costa Brava region.
Barcelona was home to world-renowned surrealist artists such as Pablo Picasso and Joan MirÃ³, as well as architect Antoni GaudÃ­â€”whose artistry as a Catalan modernist is present in the cityâ€™s landmarks such as Casa BatllÃ³ and La Sagrada Familia, scheduled to be structurally completed in 2026 after 144 years of construction.Â
Salvador DalÃ­ was also another iconic name in the surrealism movement. His friend circle ranged from David Bowie and John Lennon to Walt Diâ€¦

entry.title: When humpbacks get stuck, their friends stick around to help
Iffy about camping? Hereâ€™s how to dip your toes in.
entry.summary:
Guided camping trips aim to make the outdoors accessible and comfortable for everyone. For families who want to go camping but hesitate at the thought of figuring everything out on their own, guided camping trips can help the experience go smoothly.
â€œOur family loves the outdoors. We just donâ€™t like sleeping in it.â€ This is what I heard my 11-year-old daughter telling another girl on ourÂ campingÂ trip, who had asked where else weâ€™d beenÂ camping. The answer: Nowhere.
My family had stayed in cabins before, and some of our vacations revolved around hiking, but we usually returned to beds and showers at night. Itâ€™s not that we were nervous about sleeping in a tentâ€”we just hadnâ€™t been motivated to buy all the gear and figure it out.
But then my daughters, ages 11 and 15, said tâ€¦

entry.title: Uncovering Williamsburg and the Historic Triangle
entry.summary:
The clang of a blacksmith at work, historical reenactments and tours, beautiful scenic drives, and outdoor adventureâ€”thereâ€™s nothing quite like Williamsburg, Virginia, no matter the season.Â
History is present and alive in the rhythm of the Historic Triangle: Colonial Williamsburg, Jamestown, and Yorktown. National Geographic Photographer Greg Kahn recently traveled to this all-American region to capture this experience through the quiet, sensory details that shape memory: the clack of a horse's hoof, the flicker of firelight in a blacksmithâ€™s shop, the lap of a wave as it hits a sandy shore. It's all here in Williamsburg. undefined undefined undefined undefined In Colonial Williamsburg, the Fifes and Drums Corps preserves the powerful rhythms of 18th-century miliâ€¦

entry.title: Do fish sleep? Hereâ€™s what scientists have discovered so far
entry.summary:
A protective mucous cocoon surrounds this parrotfish as it sleeps in Australia's Great Barrier Reef. This layer of protection helps fend off predators so parrotfish can get a good night's rest. Sleep in fish may look different from humans, but rest is essential for survival. Hereâ€™s what experts have to say about fish sleep.
  If youâ€™ve ever gone snorkeling on a coral reef during the day, you likely saw waves of brightly colored fish of all shapes and sizes. But return to the same spot in the middle of the night, and most of those same creatures will have vanished.Â  Which might make one wonder, do fishÂ sleepÂ ? â€¦

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Prague
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It might be the medieval architecture or the riverside setting, the youthful atmosphere or â€” arguably â€” the worldâ€™s best beer. Whatever the reason, the Czech capital is a perennial favourite. The good news is that the shortfall in rooms of a decade ago is no longer an issue. Plenty of new hotels have opened, standards have risen and prices have moderated. Properties in the central Old Town feature historic settings and period details. For an authentic local feel, consider one of Pragueâ€™s residential quarters, like elegant Vinohrady or artsy HoleÅ¡ovice. Wherever you decide to stay, efficient public transport is always close at hand to whisk you about.
Best for: fashionistas The long-awaited reopening of the arâ€¦

entry.title: World News in Brief: UK cedes sovereignty over Chagos Islands, suffering in Sudan deepens, UN releases new emergency relief funds
entry.summary: The United Kingdom agreed to cede its control over the Chagos Islands to the Republic of Mauritius in an agreement signed between the two countries on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Civilians â€˜trapped and terrorisedâ€™: UN sounds alarm over collapse of critical protections
entry.summary: With more than 36,000 civilian deaths recorded in conflict zones in 2024 and sexual violence surging, senior UN officials warn that the international framework designed to protect civilians is collapsing.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Strikes on houses and tents responsible for over half of deaths this week
entry.summary: More than half the people killed in Gaza over the past week were in shelters and residential buildings, the UN human rights office OHCHR said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Kenya: Refugees facing â€˜lowest everâ€™ emergency food rations amid funding crisis
entry.summary: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Thursday that it has been forced to cut food aid to unprecedented lows in Kenyaâ€™s sprawling refugee camps, as a result of severe funding shortages.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres strongly condemns killing of Israeli diplomats in US capital
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has strongly condemned the â€œappalling killingâ€ of two Israeli embassy officials in the United States capital, stressing that â€œnothing can justify such a horrific act,â€ his Spokesperson said in a statement on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: SECURITY COUNCIL LIVE: Ambassadors debate safety of civilians with 36,000 lives lost during conflict last year
entry.summary: We're live as the Security Council convenes for its annual open debate on the protection of civilians in armed conflict, with briefings from UN relief chief Tom Fletcher and the head of UN Women Sima Bahous. Ambassadors will discuss evolving threats, including use of heavy weapons and the rise of lethal autonomous killing machines such as drones. The UN has documented a spike in deaths, with Gaza, Lebanon, Myanmar, Sudan and Ukraine among the hardest-hit. Mobile app users can follow here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: All eyes on Gaza as aid teams retrieve first lifesaving relief in months
entry.summary: UN agencies in Gaza confirmed on Thursday that desperately needed aid has finally arrived at warehouses inside the enclave after an 11-week blockade by Israeli authorities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate Trans-Canadian Highway road trip
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Stretching from coast to coast, the Trans-Canada Highway is a ribbon of road that stitches together the vast landscapes of Canada, from the glacier lakes of Alberta to the prairies of Manitoba. But itâ€™s the British Columbia section that arguably shines brightest, offering a wealth of experiences across some 500 miles.
The real charm of driving this route is watching the scenery beyond the windscreen switch from lush rainforest to the rugged Rocky Mountains. Take your time: six days is ideal, pausing to uncover the mysteries of old ghost towns, delve into the regionâ€™s Chinese heritage, or experience the thrill of whitewater rafting. Each stop offers a new perspective on Canadaâ€™s wild western frontier.
The advâ€¦

entry.title: Anatomy of an Ecocide: The Mysterious Poisoning of Czechiaâ€™s Becva River
entry.summary: Our investigation found that a factory owned by a former Czech prime minister should have been the prime suspect in an environmental disaster. But authorities looked elsewhere.

entry.title: Here's what to do if your flight is delayed or canceled in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Air travel can be a stressful experience, especially if your flight has been delayed or canceled. Travel experts provide ways to reduce your anxiety if youâ€™re stranded in a U.S. airport. From getting a refund to rebooking your trip, hereâ€™s what to know about handling air travel curveballsâ€”and your rights as a traveler.
In a perfect world, every flight would take off promptly and make it to its final destination 20 minutes early. But in the real world, delays and outright cancellations are all too common. From thunderstorms to mechanical issues to air traffic control snafus, there are plenty of reasons to prevent your plane from making an on-time departure. The good news is that travelers have options and access to some compensation when wait times drag on. Hereâ€™s what to know when â€¦

entry.title: How do clownfish survive a heat wave?
entry.summary:
As she checked the measurements again, Ph.D. student Melissa Versteeg was worried something was wrong with her figures. The fish seemed to be shrinking.Â
â€œShe was measuring them three times,â€ says Theresa Rueger, a marine biologist who worked with Versteeg at Newcastle University in England. â€œShe had several people measuring them at the same time to really make sure that we're confident with the numbers.â€Â
But the measurements were correct. Versteegâ€™s data showed that the individual clown anemonefish (Amphiprion percula) were actually getting shorter during a marine heat wave.
The findingsâ€”published in the journal Science Advancesâ€”mark the first ever observations of a coral reef fish shrinking because of environmental stressors. Scientists have noticed some fish shrinking atâ€¦

entry.title: This Spanish dining tradition is one of its best-kept secrets
entry.summary:
The fixed menu, which typically costs between 10 and 16 euros depending on where you're dining, includes a starter, main course, and dessert. One of Spainâ€™s most beloved lunch traditions is also one of the best ways to get an authentic, budget-friendly meal hereâ€”but most visitors have never heard of it.
Itâ€™s easy to spot when lunch has arrived in Spain. Shops, businesses, and schools shut their doors. Crowds begin to gather, spilling onto sidewalks, and packing into bars and restaurants in search of a good meal. While most visitors flock to the nearest plaza patio drawn in by signs for paella and sangria, most locals are settling into their favorite restaurants for one of Spainâ€™s most beloved food traditionsâ€”menÃº del dÃ­a.
MenÃº del dÃ­a, or menu of the day, is a rotating three-câ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 158 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Oct. 21 to 27, 2024. A total of 9,593 panelists responded out of 10,612 who were sampled, for [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/religion. Primary researcher Chip Rotolo, Research Associate Research team Alan Cooperman, Director, Religion ResearchGregory A. Smith, Senior Associate Director, Religion [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 30% of Americans Consult Astrology, Tarot Cards or Fortune Tellers
entry.summary: Most who use astrology (or a horoscope), tarot cards or a fortune teller say they do so just for fun rather than for insights about life. The post 30% of Americans Consult Astrology, Tarot Cards or Fortune Tellers appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Explore the Pantanal, Brazil's jaguar country, in photos
entry.summary: This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). Encounters with pantaneiros (local cattle herders) are common as they cross wooden bridges, essential for navigating the flooded landscape during wet season. While ranching has long coexisted with the regionâ€™s biodiversity, intensive livestock production and infrastructure development threaten the delicate balance. Published in the May 2025 issue of National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe toÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: These London landmarks star in Hollywood's biggest spy movies
entry.summary: The headquarters of the British Secret Intelligence Service (SIS or MI6) at Vauxhall Cross is just one of the star attractions featured in spy TV shows and movies, including Mission: Impossibleâ€”The Final Reckoning. From Dr. No to Mission: Impossible â€” The Final Reckoning, hereâ€™s where Hollywoodâ€™s greatest spies left their mark on the British capital. LondonÂ has been a favorite operational theater for cinematic espionage for nearly a century.Â Â The capers began with Alfred Hitchcock, who established the modern spy thriller withÂ The 39 StepsÂ in 1935, usingÂ King's Cross Station. On May 23, this tradition continues when filmgoers can catch Tom Cruise as super spy Ethan Hunt inÂ Mission: Impossible â€“ The Final Reckoning, with the city serving as the ploâ€¦

entry.title: This generation is facing a host of totally unique health threats
entry.summary:
A child in Paris watches a screen on February 14, 2024. Four ways the world has profoundly changed for today's young people, according to a comprehensive new global report.
Adolescence can be rife with anxieties and challenges, but todayâ€™s youth face unique threats on a scale encountered by no previous generation, according to an exhaustive new report on their health and wellbeing.
More than one billion people aged 10 to 24 are at risk of poor health outcomes by 2030, which is at least half the global adolescent population, concluded the report published on Tuesday in the Lancet, a leading medical journal. Adolescents are experiencing rising rates of obesity and mental health struggles, while also grappling with the influence of digital technologies and a destabilized global câ€¦

entry.title: This deadly prehistoric wasp captured prey with 'Venus flytrap' abs
entry.summary:
The 99-million-year-old fossil was preserved in amber and uncovered in Myanmar. This one-of-a-kind predatory strategy has never been seen in other insects. Scientists think it was used to trap flies into incubating the waspâ€™s eggs.
In Greek mythology, the sea monster Charybdis swallowed and regurgitated large volumes of water, creating whirlpools powerful enough to drag passing ships to their doom. Ninety-nine million years before the myth was created, in the mid-Cretaceous, the wasp Sirenobethylus charybdis deployed a similar deadly trap that recently earned it a scientific name inspired by the mythological monster.
A Venus flytrap-like structure on the waspâ€™s abdomen held captives in place as the wasp deposited its eggs into its victim, forcing it to incubate its offspring.â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 167 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 7 to April 13, 2025. A total of 3,589 panelists responded out of 4,036 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Views of how much discrimination transgender people, gay and lesbian people, women and men face in the U.S.
entry.summary: Nearly eight-in-ten Americans (77%) say there is a lot of (48%) or some (30%) discrimination against transgender people in society. And seven-in-ten Americans say there is a lot of or some discrimination in society against people who are gay or lesbian. Read the overview of this report for Americansâ€™ views of all 20 groups asked [â€¦] The post 3. Views of how much discrimination transgender people, gay and lesbian people, women and men face in the U.S. appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of how much discrimination Muslims, Jews, evangelicals and atheists face
entry.summary: Compared with last year, perceptions of discrimination against Jews and Muslims have declined among both Republicans and Democrats (including independents who lean toward each party). There also has been a modest decrease in the share of the public saying evangelical Christians face at least some discrimination, largely due to a change among Republicans. Read the [â€¦] The post 2. Views of how much discrimination Muslims, Jews, evangelicals and atheists face appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views of how much discrimination racial and ethnic groups in the U.S. face
entry.summary: Most Americans say there is at least some discrimination against Black, Hispanic and Asian people, while fewer than half say White people experience a lot of or some discrimination. These attitudes differ considerably across racial and ethnic groups. Read the overview of this report for Americansâ€™ views of all 20 groups asked about on the [â€¦] The post 1. Views of how much discrimination racial and ethnic groups in the U.S. face appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How Much Discrimination Do Americans Say Groups Face in the U.S.?
entry.summary: Republicans are less likely than in 2024 to say there is discrimination against Black, Hispanic, Asian and White people. The post How Much Discrimination Do Americans Say Groups Face in the U.S.? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: Land is sinking, or subsiding, at a slow rate of millimeters per year.â€¦ Tags: land, sinking, Washington Post

entry.title: A taste of New York's Hudson Valley
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
I pull up at Orange County Distilleryâ€™s 100-year-old barn, around an hourâ€™s drive from New York City, as chef Anthony Mario Acevedo is busy preparing pork belly on an outdoor grill. Itâ€™s a tempting scent, but before we eat, the distilleryâ€™s co-owner John Glebocki is keen to show me the surrounding estate at Brown Barn Farms. Within two minutes, aboard a farm buggy, weâ€™re out into a freshly ploughed field with soil thatâ€™s almost charcoal-black.
This 26,000-acre swathe of land, known as the Black Dirt Region, is a protected area containing some of the worldâ€™s most fertile soil. It covers much of the southern part of New York stateâ€™s Orange County, from the Hudson River at its eastern edge into parts of neighbouringâ€¦

entry.title: Why the future of fashion is â€˜farm to closetâ€™
entry.summary:
On a damp DecemberÂ morning in the mountainous district of Ambarawa in Central Java, a woman in an inky black sleeveless vest and gathered skirt balances herself on the back of a motorbike that carries her through a small village, past houses adorned with tropical plants and birdcages, and into a forest. The land here, some 300 miles east of Indonesiaâ€™s capital of Jakarta, brims with shrubs and trees that grow a variety of crops, including cassava and coffee. But itâ€™s the forest floor thatâ€™s brought Denica Riadini-Flesch, 34, to this corner of her home country. Under the shade of banana, papaya, and coconut trees, sheâ€™s trying to seed a revolutionâ€”in the form of hundreds of vibrant indigo plants, all casting a glossy viridescence across the soil.
Riadini-Flesch is the founder of Suâ€¦

entry.summary: When human rights activist Eunju Kim was 11, her mother and older sister left, telling her they were going in search of food. For six days and six nights, Ms. Kim counted from one to 100 over and over again, desperate for their return.

entry.title: Nations adopt historic pledge to guard against future pandemics
entry.summary: After three years of negotiations sparked by the COVID-19 crisis, countries have adopted the worldâ€™s first-ever international agreement to better prevent, prepare for, and respond to future pandemics. The new accord marks a major step towards ensuring stronger global cooperation to protect lives and avoid the devastating consequences of future outbreaks.

entry.title: 7 of the best new museums to visit this year
entry.summary:
Saka Museum in Bali shines a light on often-overlooked aspects of Balinese culture. From the worldâ€™s largest archaeological space dedicated to a single civilisation to a fascinating deep dive into regional BBQ, these new museums are worthy of your attention in 2025. Hereâ€™s where to visit this year.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Whether itâ€™s getting in touch with different cultures, finding creative inspiration or even sinking your teeth into the history of a specific subject, museums can be intimate and interactive spaces that conjure new trains of thought while transporting visitors into other worlds â€” even if just for a brief moment. And 2025 is a great year to wander collection-filled halls, get lost in exhibitions and stimulate the sensâ€¦

entry.title: 3 of Mexicoâ€™s lesser-known archaeological wonders
entry.summary:
The Temple of the Inscriptions at the ruins of the Maya city of Palenque, in Chiapas, Mexico. For those seeking a quieter, more affordable alternative to ChichÃ©n ItzÃ¡, these temples across the YucatÃ¡n Peninsula offer a glimpse into the rich history of the Maya.
Nestled in the jungles of the YucatÃ¡n, about 45 minutes from Valladolid, lies one of Mexicoâ€™s most visited archaeological sitesâ€”ChichÃ©n ItzÃ¡. Once a thriving Maya city with an estimated 35,000 residents, it now draws crowds of visitors from around the world to admire its grand temples and explore the regionâ€™s rich history.
Designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1988 and later named one of the New Seven Wonders of the World, ChichÃ©n ItzÃ¡ continues to break visitation records. While its significance and beauty is undeâ€¦

entry.title: Thereâ€™s more to the French Riviera than Nice or Cannes
entry.summary:
On the French Riviera, La Turbie is just one of several lesser-known cities and villages that tourists should consider visiting on the French Riviera. Add the ancient Roman Trophy of Augustus monument to your trip itinerary in La Turbie. While tourists flock to magnetic destinations like Nice and Cannes, these often overlooked small towns offer art, history, and natural beautyâ€”without the crowds.
Quiet, unspoiled, and often overlooked â€” welcome to the softer side of the French Riviera. Vence carries the artistic legacy of Matisse and Chagall. La Turbie still bears the weight of Roman ambition, its ancient monument towering over the landscape. And in Roquebrune-Cap-Martin, modernist visions and medieval myths share the same sun-drenched cliffs.
(Related: The pearl of the Frenchâ€¦

entry.title: Why this over-the-counter drug may not be worth the risk
entry.summary:
Diphenhydramine, a common antihistamine found in over-the-counter allergy and sleeping medications, may increase users' risk for dementia when taken daily over a prolonged period. Experts say the drug can also be harmful if taken in large doses beyond its recommended use. Diphenhydramine is the active ingredient in countless over-the-counter medications. But experts say there are serious risks to taking too much of the drugâ€”or taking it too long.
If youâ€™re among the one in three adults who struggles with seasonal allergies, the one in 10 dealing with some form of insomnia, or are among the millions dealing with the occasional cold or cough, chances are youâ€™ve got drugs containing diphenhydramine in your medicine cabinet. But what you may not realize is that for years doctors have bâ€¦

entry.title: Prostate problems are common as you age. Hereâ€™s what to know.
entry.summary:
Many men keep quiet about their prostate problems, but ignoring the ubiquitous health issue wonâ€™t make it go away.
About one of every eight males will be diagnosed with prostate cancer in their lives, and half of all those between 51 and 60 years old will suffer from a benign enlarged prostate. That number climbs to 70 percent among men ages 60 to 69, and 90 percent among men over 85.
Arvin George, director of the Johns Hopkins Medicine prostate cancer program, says experts donâ€™t know the exact mix of genetic, environmental, dietary, or other factors that play a role in prostate problems as men age. That means thereâ€™s no easy path to avoid them. â€œFor both an enlarged prostate and prostate cancer, thereâ€™s no â€˜apple a dayâ€™ to prevent this,â€ he says.
Fortunately, there are waysâ€¦

entry.title: Bhutanâ€™s beauty beckons tourists. Hereâ€™s how to plan your trip.
entry.summary:
Built on a sheer cliff, Paro Taktsang is also known as the Tiger's Nest Monastery. Thereâ€™s no bad time to visit this Himalayan kingdom, which has excellent hikes year-round and vibrant cultural festivals every month. Hereâ€™s how to experience it all.
Considered by some to be the real-life location of the elusive Shangri La, Bhutan is a small Himalayan enclave that also happens to be the last remaining Buddhist Kingdom in the world. Here, there are many more Buddhist temples and monasteries than days of the year, and just about as many festivals.
Add in rolling hills, dense forests, and countless never-to-be-named mountains in areas so remote that it takes a weekâ€™s worth of hiking to reach the nearest village, and you have yourself a culture-loving trekkerâ€™s dream. From two-mileâ€¦

entry.title: These capuchins are abducting babies from howler monkeysâ€”for fun?
entry.summary:
Here a white-faced capuchin monkey perches on a tree branch in Manuel Antonio National Park in Costa Rica. A group from the same genus has been observed with stolen howler monkey babies on a small island off the coast of Panama.  A young male nicknamed Joker was probably the first to start carrying a howler monkey baby on his back for days on end. Then a group of other young males started to copy him.
On a tiny island off the coast of Panama called JicarÃ³n, a male capuchin monkey called Joker appears to have started a disturbing trend.
Camera traps caught Joker, nicknamed for the scar on his face, and other male white-faced capuchins (Cebus capucinus imitator) carrying kidnapped howler monkey infants on their backs. Researchers originally set up the traps in 2017 after a â€¦

entry.title: Why this small US city packs a big culinary punch
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œOyster farming used to be really male dominated,â€ says Amy Gaiero. â€œBut thatâ€™s starting to change. Iâ€™m noticing more women out here working on the water.â€ The morning air is still so crisp that her words produce a cloud of mist over the shiny aluminium barge as we chug towards Nauti Sisters Sea Farm: a small but mighty micro-oyster venture where Amy and her sisters Alicia and Chelsea cultivate shellfish destined for Portlandâ€™s white-tablecloth restaurants.
Fresh out of college, Amy isnâ€™t your typical marine farmer: sheâ€™s young, female, sporting on-trend outdoorsy gear and â€” ironically â€” is allergic to shellfish. Yet, reeled in by the promise of harvesting low-impact, hyper-local food, the plucky fisherwoman has foâ€¦

entry.title: Drone strikes on civilian infrastructure in Port Sudan must end: UN expert
entry.summary: Repeated drone strikes over the past two weeks in Port Sudan have damaged key infrastructure across the crucial Sudanese aid hub, disrupted humanitarian operations, and placed civilians in danger, a UN-appointed human rights expert has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Terror-crime link alarm, child detention in Australia, judiciary in Maldives, Protection of Civilians Week
entry.summary: The head of the UN Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), called on Monday for renewed global commitment to combating emerging criminal threats and strengthening justice systems worldwide.

entry.title: UN faces deepening financial crisis, urges members to pay up
entry.summary: The United Nations is facing a worsening cash crisis that threatens its ability to carry out vital work, Member States warned this week, as the General Assemblyâ€™s Fifth Committee met to discuss the world bodyâ€™s financial health.

entry.title: Home-bound Syrians find few of the basics needed to survive
entry.summary: Syrians trying to rebuild their lives in their war-torn country urgently need the support of the rest of the world to help them start again, UN aid agencies insist.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World Health Assembly opens amid high-stakes pandemic treaty vote, global funding crisis
entry.summary: The 78thÂ World Health Assembly opened on Monday with a broad appeal to global solidarity, as delegates from around the world gather in Geneva to confront mounting health, climate, and financial challenges â€“ and finalise a global treaty to head off the next pandemic.

entry.title: UN relief chief welcomes limited Gaza aid resumption â€“ but itâ€™s a â€˜drop in the oceanâ€™
entry.summary: The UN humanitarian affairs chief has welcomed Israelâ€™s decision to allow limited aid to cross into Gaza after 11 weeks of complete blockade â€“ but significantly more is needed â€œstarting tomorrow morningâ€.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: International Criminal Court: Deputies take over amid Prosecutor misconduct probe
entry.summary: The Deputy Prosecutors of the International Criminal Court have assumed leadership of the Office of the Prosecutor following Karim Khanâ€™s decision to take a leave of absence amid an ongoing UN investigation into allegations of misconduct against him.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Israel â€˜approaches UNâ€™ to resume limited aid deliveries, says aid agency
entry.summary: Amid intensifying Israeli bombing and ground operations in Gaza, the UNâ€™s relief coordination agency, OCHA, said on Monday that it was in talks with Israel to re-start deliveries of lifesaving supplies to the stricken enclave.

entry.title: GIJN Webinar: Behind the Data â€” Tools and Techniques from the 2025 Sigma Award Winners
entry.summary: In this fast-paced session, winning teams will each have five minutes to share key insights from their reporting process â€” from their favorite tools to innovative methods that helped uncover complex stories. Moderated by journalist and newsroom leader Gina Chua, the session offers a unique, behind-the-scenes look at the workflows powering award-winning journalism.

entry.title: From Flammable Buildings to Slaveryâ€™s Hidden Legacy to Tainted Groundwater: Projects from 10 Countries Win GIJNâ€™s 2025 Sigma Awards
entry.summary: Ten outstanding data-driven journalism projects, from as many countries, were chosen by a diverse Prize Committee of 17 judges from 498 entries from 80 countries.

entry.title: In Baghdad, Guterres affirms UN will never forget staff killed in Canal Hotel attack
entry.summary: The United Nations will never forget the staff members killed nearly 23 years ago in the attack on its headquarters in Iraq, the Secretary-General said in the capital on Sunday.

entry.title: Why now's the time to visit underrated Sierra Leone
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The storm is clearing now, though the occasional bolt of lightning illuminates our passage. As my eyes slowly adapt, the world around me reveals itself in flickers and bursts: slender palms bent in prayer over the silent water; the villager to my left clutching a brace of pucker-mouthed catfish; fireflies darting like embers through the gloom.
Weâ€™re bound for Tiwai, a remote river island of 4sq miles situated in one of the last portions of ancient rainforest in West Africa. We set off from Freetown that morning, leaving the capitalâ€™s blue-green shores to follow increasingly non-existent roads east into Sierra Leoneâ€™s Southern Province. It hasnâ€™t been an easy journey to this point, but with the first stars glimmerinâ€¦

entry.title: These coastal activities are on the riseâ€”here's how to try them
entry.summary:
â€œGliding from bridge to island and island to bridge, with the Seto Inland Sea stretching endlessly around you, is a truly unforgettable experience,â€ says Miho Ogura, co-founder of Hidden Japan Travel. Kayak camping, coasteering and culinary tours â€” experts share six up-and-coming WAYS to experience the worldâ€™s shores.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The coast has always held a magnetic pull. Itâ€™s where we walk for clarity, drawn by the hypnotic crash of waves; where we plunge into saltwater, emerging recharged; and where we linger at sunset, captivated by the endless horizon. Research shows that being near water can lower stress and enhance wellbeing â€”Â a feeling many travellers are now actively seeking. Fortunately, thereâ€™s no shortage of coaâ€¦

entry.title: Where to eat in Vancouver's best food neighborhoods
entry.summary:
Vancouver's best food neighbourhoods offer everything from chic, Chinatown speakeasys to Michelin Guide-recommended small plates. A guide to eating and drinking around the city, from the food counters of Granville Island to the â€˜Michelin mileâ€™ of Mount Pleasant.
This story was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Sandwiched between mountains and Pacific Ocean waves, Vancouver is most often lauded for its phenomenal natural setting, with its skyscrapers brushing up against the old-growth trees of Stanley Park. But the largest city in British Columbia is increasingly becoming known for dining, too, with the Michelin Guide finally awarding the city a constellation of stars in 2022. Each of Vancouverâ€™s neighbourhoods offers something different â€” the product of immigrâ€¦

entry.title: UN humanitarian chief demands resumption of aid in Gaza
entry.summary: Humanitarians demand access to the Gaza Strip and already have a plan in place to deliver life-saving aid to civilians, UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Tom Fletcher said in a strong call issued late on Friday evening.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Civilians killed in drone strike in eastern Ukraine: UN rights monitors
entry.summary: A drone strike in eastern Ukraine on Saturday could possibly be the deadliest in recent weeks, the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in the country, HRMMU, has said.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: At Arab League Summit, Guterres reiterates call for Gaza ceasefire
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General renewed his call for a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip and upheld the need for a two-State solution between Israelis and Palestinians in a speech on Saturday to the League of Arab States Summit in Baghdad.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Pandemic accord can be a â€˜gamechangerâ€™ for marginalised communities, says youth advocate
entry.summary: An international pandemic prevention treaty, three years in the making, is set to be adopted this week in Geneva. Rehman Hassan, a prominent member of the UN World Health Organization (WHO) Youth Council, is confident the accord could make a huge difference to the way that the world reacts to pandemics.

entry.title: How did the the Han dynasty bury their royals?
entry.summary:
Rising over the Mancheng district, 120 miles south of Beijing, is Lingshan. More than 2,000 years ago, thousands of tons of rock were removed from its eastern slope to create complex tombs housing the remains of an elite couple: Liu Sheng, prince of Zhongshan, and his wife, Dou Wan.
Miraculously unlooted for the next two millennia, the tombsâ€™ 1960s discovery stunned archaeologists, not only for their engineering but also for the dazzling grave goods they contained. The coupleâ€™s remains were wrapped in jade burial suits now regarded as some of Chinaâ€™s greatest national treasures.
Liu Shengâ€™s father, Jing Di, was the sixth emperor of the Han, the second of Chinaâ€™s imperial dynasties, which ruled between 206 B.C.and A.D. 220. Beset with rebellions, in 154 B.C., Jing Di sent Liu Shâ€¦

entry.title: Colon cancer is rising in young people. Finally, scientists have a clue about why.
entry.summary:
Colored scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of a macrophage white blood cell (center) that is being destroyed by toxins released by E. coli bacteria (red). Some strains of E. coli release colibactin, a toxin which damages the DNA of cells, and may contribute to the development of colorectal cancer. As scientists question the rise in early colon cancer cases, a new study is offering some potential answers.
Colorectal cancer should be on your radar: Today, one in five people under the age of 54 is diagnosed with the disease, marking an 11 percent uptick in this age group over the past two decades. What, exactly, is fueling the surge in younger patients has perplexed scientists and medical professionals alike.
(Colon cancer is rising among young adults. Here are signs to watch forâ€¦

entry.title: Ancient Greeks and Romans were obsessed with diet advice, too
entry.summary:
Ancient Roman still-life mosaic fish and vegetables, 2nd century, from a villa at Tor Marancia. Vatican Museums, Rome From protein-filled meals to the benefits of lentils and intermittent fasting, the Classical world had strong opinions about how to stay healthy.
Before Instagram trends and DNA-based diets, Greek and Roman physicians used diet as the primary form of healthcare. Shockingly, their advice seems both modern and remarkably sensible. Too much red meat (specifically beef) could lead to cancer, wrote the second century-CE Roman medic Galen. Those who were looking to lose weight, wrote Hippocrates, should try what we call fasting cardio: exercising on an empty stomach before eating. And chicken soup, wrote Dioscorides, the father of pharmacology, â€œis very often given to thoâ€¦

entry.title: Got food poisoning? One of these 4 bugs is likely the cause
entry.summary:
A color enhanced transmission electron micrograph shows a listeria bacterium in tissue. This pathogen is the third-leading cause of death from foodborne illness in the United States. Infections are typically linked to unpasteurized raw milk, hot dogs, dry sausages, smoked seafood, and salads, to name a few.  Listeria. E. Coli. Salmonella. Norovirus. Here's what to know about these common culprits of foodborne illnessâ€”and how to keep them from spreading.
As temperatures continue to rise, so too does the risk of food poisoning.Â
U.S. officials are currently investigating an upsurge of listeria cases linked to ready-to-eat foods such as sandwiches and protein snacks.
About 48 million people in the U.S.(about one in six) fall prey to a foodborne pathogen every year, accoâ€¦

entry.title: Avoid the crowds at U.S. national parksâ€”by going underwater
entry.summary:
The underwater kelp forests at Anacapa Island in Channel Islands National Park. From sunken ships to kelp forests to vibrant reefs, these national park experiences are as uncrowded as it gets. Hereâ€™s where to go.
You might know the phrase â€œhalf the park is after dark,â€ a National Park Service campaign designed to spread out visitors and encourage them to explore in new ways. But to avoid the crowds in the countryâ€™s most beloved places, going out under the moonlight isnâ€™t the only option for seclusionâ€”you can go underwater.
And itâ€™s not just the nationâ€™s coastal parks that offer watery worlds to explore. From the bubbles of Yellowstone to the shipwrecks of Isle Royale, the parks below offer uncommon, unparalleled experiencesâ€”where the only crowds come with fins, flippers, and gâ€¦

entry.title: Regenerated organs are tantalizingly close
entry.summary:
Stem cells (like the ones above, growing in petri dishes) are able to differentiate into any type of cell in the body, including cells that generate and repair tissue that's been damaged by disease. After decades of hype and setbacks, scientists have made impressive progress into tricking stem cells into repairing organs.
In the 1986 movie Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home, Dr. McCoy hands a dialysis patient a single pill and she immediately grows a new kidney. Thatâ€™s the holy grail of regenerative medicine, and it has proven frustratingly elusive.
When disease damages crucial organs like the heart or lungs, the best doctors can generally do is stop the harm from worsening. Now, after three decades of trial and error, the prospect of revving up the bodyâ€™s own stem cells to become â€¦

entry.title: Where to taste Greeceâ€™s best olive oil
entry.summary:
According to Greek mythology, Athena planted the first olive tree on the Acropolis. From tastings with olive oil sommeliers to celebrating harvest season at family-run mills, hereâ€™s how to experience oleotourism and immerse yourself in the world of Greeceâ€™s â€œliquid gold.â€
The silvery-green olive trees that blanket Greece are as rooted in its culture as the stars and sea. According to Greek mythology, Athena planted the first olive tree on the Acropolis, triumphing over Poseidon to become Athensâ€™ patron goddessâ€”forever cementing the evergreen as a sacred symbol of prosperity. In ancient Greece, Olympic victors were crowned with olive branches, while Homer referred to the antioxidant-rich juice as â€œliquid goldâ€ in his epic poems. Today, Greece remains one of the worldâ€™s top olive oilâ€¦

entry.title: How to spend two days in Tofino on Vancouver Island
entry.summary:
Tofino Harbour is the gateway to Clayoquot Sound's 60-mile-wide stretch of water, home to Tofinoâ€™s islands and inlets. Windswept surfing beaches, rainforest hikes and seaweed spas are all on offer at this bohemian outpost on Vancouver Island.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Set on Vancouver Islandâ€™s wild western shore, Tofino is a town surrounded by windswept beaches and coastal rainforest. It has a hippy air and is home to year-round surfers, Indigenous artists and an increasing number of chefs, drawn to the natural riches of the Pacific coast. Come for ocean waves, stay for the fish tacos and star-spangled evenings.
8am: Breakfast at the beach Start the day at Cox Bay, a mile-long stretch of sand just south of Tofino. The Beach Shackâ€¦

entry.title: Can humans smell insects? The truth about the viral debate
entry.summary:
Ladybugs lay down "trails" of scents to help guide other ladybugs to a meetup spot. People on TikTok are arguing about it, so we asked the experts to weigh in.
Itâ€™s an ongoing debate onÂ TikTok: A couple wonders why one of them can smell ladybugs and the other canâ€™t.Â
Below that video, one commenter notes that ants smell, too, like a â€œcombo of tomato vine and dirt.â€Â
Another commenterÂ says the ant smell is more like â€œblue cheese or pen ink.â€Â Â
And one less fortunateÂ commenter notes: â€œI can smell roaches. Itâ€™s the worst superpower I have ever developed.â€Â
Just like â€œthe dressâ€ divided the internet a decade ago, the insect smell question is one of the latest debates.Â
So, why do some people pick up these odors, while others donâ€™t? The answer goes back to howâ€¦
