entry.title: Pandemic heroes stepped up in 2020 â€“ now theyâ€™re asking world leaders to do the same
entry.summary: As world leaders negotiate the landmark Pandemic Preparedness Treaty at the WHO Assembly, we revisit frontline doctors, community advocates, a youth volunteer, and a journalist who lived through the storm of COVID-19. Theirs are just some of the millions of testimonies worldwide helping shape the urgent call for action.

entry.summary: The United Nations Secretary-General warned on Friday that Himalayan glaciers are â€œcaving in,â€ urging immediate action to address the climate crisis, especially in the worldâ€™s most fragile ecosystems.

entry.summary: The military authorities in Mali have dissolved all political parties and repealed laws protecting political participation, drawing sharp condemnation from the UNâ€™s top human rights official on Friday.

entry.title: End senseless killings in the West Bank: UN rights office
entry.summary: The UN human rights office (OHCHR) called on Friday for an end to senseless killings in the occupied West Bank, where a pregnant Israeli woman was among the latest victims.

entry.title: Another year, another rise in food insecurity â€“ including famine
entry.summary: In July 2024, famine was detected in the Sudanâ€™s Zamzam IDP camp. In the following months, the official alert expanded to other camps in Darfur and Western Nuba Mountains. From December until now, famine has beenÂ confirmed in five other areas of the war-torn country. A further 17 areas are at risk.

entry.summary: Amid reports that Israeli strikes across Gaza overnight into Friday killed at least 64 people, aid teams once again pushed back strongly at allegations that aid is being diverted to Hamas, demanding an end to Israelâ€™s blockade.

entry.title: We could still save the worldâ€™s most adorable dolphin
entry.summary:
An orphaned Irrawaddy dolphin rests in the arms of its caretaker at the Marine Endangered Species Veterinary Hospital in Rayong, Thailand. Irrawaddy dolphins have captured hearts for generations for their adorable smirks and ability to help humans catch fish. Now it's our turn to help them.
On Myanmarâ€™s Ayeyarwady River, fishers tap the side of their boats and wait. If theyâ€™re lucky, a gray dolphin with a rounded head and smirk appears. These are Irrawaddy dolphinsâ€”social, intelligent mammals that have fished alongside humans for generations. The dolphins herd fish toward the fishersâ€™ cast nets, and in return, they snag fish trapped near the edges or stuck in the mud at the bottom for themselves.Â
One dolphin, named Gotama, is even known for giving a special signalâ€”a flicâ€¦

entry.title: You canâ€™t tell the story of New Orleans without its Black Catholics
entry.summary: A member of the Treme Brass Band plays during a concert marking the anniversary of Hurricane Katrina Concert at the historically black St. Augustine Catholic Church in New Orleans, Louisiana. Founded in 1841, St. Augustine is the oldest Black parish in the United States and was the place of worship for some of the city's most influential historical figures. The revelation that Pope Leo XIV has Louisiana Creole roots shines a light on a community of Catholics that has shaped New Orleans, from a famous Voodoo priestess to the self-proclaimed inventor of jazz. The election of Pope Leo XIV as the first American pontiffâ€”and the subsequent revelation that he has Louisiana Creole rootsâ€”shines new light on a cityâ€¦

entry.title: This ancient port in England is having a 21st-century renaissance
entry.summary:
Hastings is popular in the spring and summer, when the sunlit sea is turquoise, the seafront rides are in full swing and the entire town heads out for Jack in the Green â€” a day of folk dancing, parades and merriment held on May Day. Tradition and innovation combine in this historic port town on the East Sussex coast in southern England.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Mention Hastings and people still refer to the battle of 1066, which is a shame given the town has changed so much â€” since the 11th century, certainly, but over the past decade, too. Like many British seaside resorts, Hastings and its neighbour, St Leonards-on-Sea, had their heyday in the Victorian era before falling into a period of decline. Their revivals in recent years haveâ€¦

entry.title: Can food bring people together? Stanley Tucci thinks so.
entry.summary: Stanley Tucci, host of the new series Tucci in Italy, ventures beyond Rome to Lazio's less-visited countryside to understand the relationship between the ancient metropolis and rural heartland. From a pine-needle pesto in Trentino-Aldo Adige to a Roman pizza in Lazio, the host of Tucci in Italy tells us about the dishes and people that define some of Italyâ€™s most distinct regions. Stanley Tucciâ€™s new series has been 20 years in the making â€” or at least, thatâ€™s how long itâ€™s been since the idea first struck him. His mission? To ignite curiosity, not only about Italy, but the ways in which we can explore the world through food.Â Tucci in Italy, which premieres May 18 on National Geographic, follows the acclaimed actor and author as he navigates the culinary traâ€¦

entry.title: A practical guide to exploring the Alps' classic highlights
entry.summary:
Roads in the Alps are generally well maintained and signposted, but youâ€™ll need to be a confident driver to tackle inclines and hairpin bends. These mountains have long been winter favourites, and theyâ€™re now becoming increasingly popular in the summer, too. Hereâ€™s what to keep in mind when planning a warm-weather visit.  
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Wild as they are, the Alps are brilliantly accessible in the warmer months, whether you want to devise your own multi-day, cross-country trip on the frequent, efficient trains, or hit the trail on a long-distance, hut-to-hut hike. For planning, booking and money-saving tips, try this handy guide.
Pack for the outdoors. Bring layers: a breathable fleece, loose walking trousers, hikâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜We are still waiting for our loved onesâ€™: Families of the abducted speak out
entry.summary: Two families â€“ one still waiting for answers 75 years after a father was taken during the Korean War, the other pleading for a sonâ€™s return from captivity in Gaza â€“ shared their testimonies before the UN Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: New displacement orders force thousands to flee as famine looms
entry.summary: Intensified hostilities continue in the Gaza Strip, bringing further death, displacement and destruction as the weeks-long aid blockade grinds on, the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA) said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudden escalation of trade tensions sends shockwaves through global economy
entry.summary: Amid escalating trade tensions and growing policy uncertainties, the global economy stands at a fragile turning point, according to a new report on Thursday from the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN needed â€˜more than ever beforeâ€™ says Germanyâ€™s candidate to head General Assembly
entry.summary: The former Foreign Minister of Germany outlined her vision for the role of UN General Assembly President, pledging to make the world body more effective, inclusive and focused on results.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Over 60 per cent of the Arab world still outside the banking system
entry.summary: Between 2016 and 2024, the number of Egyptians with a bank account â€“ which experts say is essential for financial inclusion - tripled, from 17.1 million to over 51 million.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Libyaâ€™s fragile peace tested again as new clashes roil Tripoli
entry.summary: A fragile calm has settled over Tripoli after a sudden surge of violence this week left parts of the city in ruins, claimed civilian lives, and heightened concerns about the stability of Libyaâ€™s already fragile political and security situation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜The world is failing its health checkup,â€™ says WHO
entry.summary: In just two years, between 2019 and 2021, life expectancy worldwide fell by 1.8 years â€“ the largest fall in recent history according to the World Health Organization (WHO), in the shadow of the COVID-19 pandemic.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Listening to birds sing really does soothe your brain. Hereâ€™s why.
entry.summary: A European robin, Erithacus rubecula, sings in a tree in Norfolk, England. Studies have linked the sound of birdsong to reduced levels of depression and anxiety. Spending time in nature is important for your mental health. But studies show that even just listening to birds singing can ease symptoms of anxiety and depression. Each spring, as billions of birds head north during peak migration, their melodic songs become impossible to drown outâ€”not that you would want to. Their â€œdawn chorusâ€ signals that brighter, warmer days are finally here. Itâ€™s also a scientifically proven balm for your brain. Scientists know that nature is a salve for the soul. Getting outdoors keeps your body active. Spending time in the forest lowers your stress, heart rate, and blood pressure. Gaziâ€¦

entry.title: The real-life rise and fall of Griselda Blanco
entry.summary:
Griselda Blanco is suspected of being involved in 40 murders across the U.S., including all three of her husbands. At its height, her network was pushing $80 million a month in cocaine. How did a girl who grew up in poverty in Colombia become an international narcotics queenpin pushing $80 million a month in cocaine?
The Godmother. The Black Widow. Queenpin. Griselda Blancoâ€™s many aliases and nicknames speak to the notoriety she gained by heading a billion-dollar, blood-soaked drug empire that stretched from Colombia to the United States.
The subject of the Netflixâ€™s Emmy nominated seriesÂ Griselda, Blancoâ€™s life blurred the line between fact and fiction as she clawed her way to a position of powerÂ in a violent world. So, who was the real woman behind the myth?
Blanco waâ€¦

entry.title: Mark Synnott isn't afraid to be reckless
entry.summary: Writer Mark Synnottâ€™s ship, Polar Sun, navigates the northwest passage during a 2022 attempt to retrace the steps of famed British Explorer John Franklin. The adventurer and author of Into the Ice recounts his harrowing attempt to sail the Northwest Passage and why he always listens to his gut. In 2022, Mark Synnott set sail from his home in Maine to complete the Northwest Passage, the legendary route through the Arctic that connects the Atlantic and Pacific. Synnott wanted to retrace the path of an 1845 expedition led by British explorer Sir John Franklin, who was attempting to chart the sea route over North America and open a valuable trade avenue with East Asia. But along the way Franklinâ€™s two ships, Erebus and Terror, became trapped in the ice, stranding the expâ€¦

entry.title: A historic course correction: how the worldâ€™s shipping sector is setting sail for net zero
entry.summary: Long overlooked as a major contributor to global greenhouse gas emissions, the shipping industry is now at the forefront of a unique display of international cooperation. The shift signals that even the worldâ€™s largest transport sector can be steered toward climate accountability.

entry.title: 8 million teens in world's wealthiest countries functionally illiterate: UNICEF
entry.summary: Children in many of the worldâ€™s wealthiest countries saw marked declines in their academic performance, mental wellbeing, and physical health as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a new report published by the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Funding cuts in Afghanistan mean â€˜lives lost and lives less livedâ€™
entry.summary: In a remote village clinic in the Bamyan Province in Afghanistan last week, a group of teenage girls were given potentially life-saving reproductive health advice, excited by the small kit of menstrual supplies they had been given.

entry.title: â€˜Politically unacceptable, morally repugnantâ€™: UN chief calls for global ban on 'killer robots'

entry.title: UN aid office denounces attacks on Gaza hospital
entry.summary: The UN humanitarian affairs office, OCHA, underlined the need to protect civilians and healthcare facilities in the Gaza Strip in a renewed appeal on Wednesday.

entry.title: In Berlin, broad backing for UN peacekeeping as global threats mount
entry.summary: More than 130 countries and international partners threw their weight behind UN peacekeeping at a high-level ministerial summit in Berlin on Wednesday, pledging military, tech and political support.

entry.title: US-Houthi ceasefire â€˜a welcome opportunityâ€™ to advance peace efforts in Yemen
entry.summary: The ceasefire between the United States and Houthi rebels in Yemen provides an opportunity to revitalize the peace process in the Middle Eastern country, the UN Security Council heard on Wednesday.

entry.title: Passports Are Key to Uncovering Offshore Secrecy â€” We Use Machine Learning to Find Them Efficiently
entry.summary: Passports can help unlock secret ownership of offshore companies, but finding them is often challenging. At ICIJ, we decided to build a new detection tool to speed up this process.

entry.title: Video: How common are spiritual beliefs in the U.S.?

entry.title: How changing the way you breathe can improve your brain and body
entry.summary:
If youâ€™ve ever been told to â€œtake a deep breathâ€ during a stressful moment, know that this advice isnâ€™t merely a platitudeâ€”itâ€™s backed by science.
Research shows conscious breathing comes with a host of immediate and long-term benefits that include improved heart health, reduced anxiety, boosted mood, improved cognitive function, and better sleep quality.
â€œBreathwork is one of the simplest and profoundly effective tools we have for calming the nervous system and boosting physical and mental resilience,â€ says Guy Fincham, founder of the breathwork lab at Brighton & Sussex Medical School in England and co-author ofÂ breathwork research.Â â€œAnd yet, precisely because itâ€™s so accessible, its power is often underestimated.â€Â
Hereâ€™s why mindful inhaling and exhaling can be so good foâ€¦

entry.title: Dogs. Bedbugs. Corn. They all have this one thing in common.
entry.summary:
Scientists are trying to define the situationship between domestic animals and humans. Under a new definition, populations of dogs and bedbugs are in, while horses and pigs are out.  You might think you know which animals and plants are considered "domesticated" or â€œdomesticâ€ and which ones aren'tâ€”but a new definition has launched a big debate among scientists.
Your pet pug is without a doubt a domestic dog. A cow on a farm seems domestic, too. But what about an indoor/outdoor cat, that brings home unwelcome gifts? What about animals that live in our homes to our chagrin, like a rat or a bedbug?
Even among scientists, there is no universally agreed upon definition of what domestication looks like or what makes an animal â€œdomestic.â€ Elinor Karlsson and Kathryn Lord faced tâ€¦

entry.summary: This is a Pew Research Center analysis from the Pew-Knight Initiative, a research program funded jointly by The Pew Charitable Trusts and the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation. Find related reports online at https://www.pewresearch.org/pew-knight/. Research Kirsten Eddy, Senior ResearcherKaterina Eva Matsa, Director, News and Information ResearchMichael Lipka, Associate Director, News and Information ResearchNaomi [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: What Is News?
entry.summary: As people are exposed to more information from more sources than ever before, how they define and feel about â€œnewsâ€ has become less clear-cut. The post What Is News? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This Pew Research Center study uses a multimethod approach to understanding what â€œnewsâ€ means to Americans today. The project includes three different types of research methodologies: a qualitative online discussion board with 57 U.S. adults, a nationally representative survey of 9,482 U.S. adults conducted through Pew Research Centerâ€™s American Trends Panel (ATP), and on-the-record, in-depth [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Remember the Ice Bucket Challenge? Itâ€™s back.
entry.summary:
People participate in the "Ice Bucket Challenge" in Gloucester, MA during the last annual "Plunge 4 Pete" on Dec. 28, 2019, what would have been Pete Frates' 35th birthday. The fundraiser started in 2012 after Frates' diagnosis of ALS, and eventually helped popularize the Ice Bucket Challenge. The 2014 social media trend put the spotlight on unanswered questions and needed treatments for ALS. Will its return help? We asked the father of one of the original Ice Bucket Challenge founders.
More than a decade after the viral trend first got its start, thousands of people are dusting off their buckets and dumping ice water on their heads all over againâ€”but this time, for mental health.
The viral 2014 Ice Bucket Challenge raised $115 million in six weeks for what was, at the time, aâ€¦

entry.title: Why Panama City's appeal goes far beyond its namesake canal
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At first glance, Panama City is all flashy skyline, its slew of sparkling high-rises towering above the waters of the bay like a cartoon vision of a futuristic metropolis. But the so-called â€˜Miami of Central Americaâ€™ has a hidden history â€” one that extends far beyond the canal that first put it on most travellersâ€™ mental map.
Panama is effectively a borderland between Central and South America, and its famous canal â€” built in the early 1900s â€” slices the country in two. This 51-mile waterway is a giant shortcut, connecting the Pacific and Atlantic oceans, sparing sea travellers an 8,000-mile voyage around the continentâ€™s southern tip. Each year, billions of dollarsâ€™ worth of cargo travel along it, and the comings aâ€¦

entry.title: Could beavers be the secret to the fight against wildfires?

author.name: Ben Goldfarb, Ronan Donovan, Kholood Eid

entry.title: The real science of brain rot
entry.summary:
In 2024, the Oxford University Press declared â€œbrain rotâ€ the word of the year. If Ohio is just a midwestern state to you and mewwing is something your cat does, you might not be as familiar with the term as those who have adopted the Gen Z and Alpha lexicons that popularized it. Still, youâ€™ve probably encountered its effects.
â€œBrain rotâ€ describes the supposed mental decline resulting from too much time spent in the chasms of the digital world reserved for trivial content. But, while endless hours scrolling on TikTok may prompt a headache, strained eyes, and the latest trending sound to loop in your head, â€œyour brain doesnâ€™t literally rot until after death,â€ says Andy McKenzie, a neuroscientist who studies functional brain preservation at the nonprofit Apex Neuroscience in Oregon. Anâ€¦

entry.title: Why there's a 10,000-person wait list to scavenge Londonâ€™s Thames
entry.summary:
ON A SUMMER DAY in central London, a 44-year-old woman named Lucy Peel descended a slippery stairway on the bank of the River Thames to crouch on her hands and knees over a particularly intriguing pile of mud. It was low tide, and the waters of the river had receded substantially. Ignoring the obvious tangles of trashâ€”plastic bags, vape pens, broken glassâ€”Peel painstakingly scanned the exposed riverbed until she spotted something nestled in the sand that could easily be mistaken for a leaf. After carefully prying it loose, she held up a wafer-thin ceramic shard and had a familiar feeling that she was holding a piece of ancient history.
Later, an archaeologist would confirm her suspicion: It was a fragment of Roman pottery. â€œEven though itâ€™s so fine, somehow itâ€™s still survived 2,000 yâ€¦

entry.title: UK's 'restaurants with rooms' offer a gourmet meal and a stay
entry.summary:
The Pig near Bath, in the Mendip Hills, has an extensive kitchen garden, with beds of greens, roots, herbs and fruit â€” as well as a mushroom-growing shed. These gourmet getaways offer world-class cuisine and stylish bedrooms, all under one roof.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A meal at a great destination restaurant is the ideal activity around which to plan a trip â€” and what better way to extend the experience than by checking in overnight and doing it all again at breakfast the next day? Restaurants with rooms, where you come for the food and stay for the, well, stay can be found all over the UK. Here are some of our favourites, from a former pub in Yorkshire to a castle in the Scottish Highlands.
Having started life in the New â€¦

entry.title: â€˜Stop the 21st century atrocityâ€™ in Gaza, Fletcher urges UN Security Council
entry.summary: No aid has entered Gaza for more than 10 weeks and every single one of the 2.1 million people there faces famine conditions, the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Tom Fletcher said on Tuesday in a briefing to the Security Council in New York.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Half of womenâ€™s organizations in crisis zones risk closure within six months
entry.summary: Womenâ€™s organisations operating in crisis settings are being pushed to the brink by widespread funding cuts. In a report published on Tuesday, UN Women â€“ the UN agency for gender equality â€“ warned that 47 per cent of these groups may be forced to close within the next six months.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: GAZA LIVE: 'Humanity, the law and reason must prevail' in Gaza, UN relief chief tells Security Council
entry.summary: The Security Council is meeting in New York to discuss the horror of Gaza, where humanitarians warn of â€œa critical risk of famineâ€ and aid shipments have been blocked by Israel for over 70 days. UN relief chief Tom Fletcher briefed the Security Council, asking ambassadors if they will act decisively "to prevent genocide" and ensure respect for international law. He also called on Hamas to release all hostages and stop putting civilians at risk. Follow live for key updates from UN Headquarters and reports from the region. App users can follow coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US deportations raise serious human rights concerns
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights High Commissioner Volker TÃ¼rk has voiced concern over the recent deportation of large numbers of non-nationals from the United States, particularly to third countries.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Number of internally displaced breaks new record with no let-up in conflicts, disasters
entry.summary: A record 83.4 million people have been forced from their homes around the world, fuelled by an increase in disasters and conflict, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As funding cuts bite, UN chief announces new dawn for peacekeeping
entry.summary: The future of peacekeeping took centre stage on Tuesday in Berlin as UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres urged Member States to do more to support the global bodyâ€™s 'blue helmets' and stave off the worst impacts of deep funding cuts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: 57 children reported dead from malnutrition, says WHO
entry.summary: In the aid desert of Gaza, malnourished children are dying while survivors can now expect a lifetime of dire health problems, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aviation council finds Russia responsible for downing of Malaysian Airlines flight
entry.summary: A UN body has found that Russia was responsible for the 17 July 2014 downing of Malaysian Airlines flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine that killed all 298 people on board.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 2025 Global Shining Light Award Finalists: Small and Medium Outlets
entry.summary: Six intrepid investigative projects from small and medium news outlets have been selected by GIJN as finalists for the 2025 Global Shining Light Awards.

Today we are happy to introduce a new blazing fast OpenAI Whisper deployment option on [Inference Endpoints](https://endpoints.huggingface.co). ä¸­æ–‡ç¿»è¯‘ï¼šä»Šå¤©æˆ‘ä»¬å¾ˆé«˜å…´åœ¨ [Inference Endpoints](https://endpoints.huggingface.co) ä¸Šæ¨å‡ºä¸€ç§æé€Ÿçš„ OpenAI Whisper éƒ¨ç½²é€‰é¡¹ã€‚ The new Whisper endpoint leverages amazing open-source community projects. ä¸­æ–‡ç¿»è¯‘ï¼šæ–°çš„ Whisper ç«¯ç‚¹åˆ©ç”¨äº†ä¼˜ç§€çš„å¼€æºç¤¾åŒºé¡¹ç›®ã€‚ Whisper Large V3 shows a nearly 8x improvement in RTFxï¼Œ enabling much faster inference with no loss in transcription quality. ä¸­æ–‡ç¿»è¯‘ï¼šWhisper Large V3 åœ¨ RTFx æ–¹é¢æ˜¾ç¤ºäº†è¿‘ 8 å€çš„æ”¹è¿›ï¼Œä»è€Œåœ¨ä¸æŸå¤±è½¬å½•è´¨é‡çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹å®ç°æ›´å¿«çš„æ¨ç†ã€‚ ğŸ“Š æ–‡ç« ä¿¡æ¯

entry.title: Tariff timeline with China, so far
entry.summary: The U.S. and China put a semi-hold on tariffs for the next 90â€¦ Tags: China, New York Times, tariff

entry.title: English wine is on the rise. Here is where to experience it
entry.summary:
Domaine Evremond, established by Taittinger, produces Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier vines on its south-facing slopes in Kent. Savour the best of English wine with new festivals and vineyard experiences.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There was a time, not so long ago really, when English oenophiles looking to set up shop had no choice but to relocate to the balmier climes of France or Italy. Not anymore. A changing climate, a culture of experimentation and greater awareness of which regions are best suited to grape growing have combined to make England one of Europeâ€™s most exciting viticultural destinations â€” and it shows. Across the country, youâ€™ll find tours and tastings that showcase some of Englandâ€™s best homegrown producers. â€¦

entry.title: Alcohol is killing more women than ever before
entry.summary:
Jasmine Charbonierâ€™s heavy drinking started in college. By her early 30s, she was downing up to eight tequila cocktails daily, several days each week. A few years ago she tried to quit and was surprised when she plummeted into withdrawal.
Research shows that while men are still more likely to die from an alcohol-related disease, the gap is narrowing. The most recent figures, published in 2024, found deaths in women have risen at a rate of 35 percent, while men increased just 27 percent.
(8 things we've learned about how alcohol harms the body.)
The rise in deaths results from an unfortunate gender equality: Women now raise their glass almost as frequently as men. A recent U.S. government survey found 45 percent of women drank in the prior month, compared to 50 percent of menâ€¦

entry.title: The secret program that brought Nazi scientists to the U.S.
entry.summary:
On July 20, 1969, a crew of American astronauts successfully landed on the moon for the first time. Though only three of them were in the spacecraft, thousands of people had contributed their brainpower to put the astronauts in flight.
Among the contributors: German scientists who had been members of the Nazi Party. The United States recruited them in the years after World War IIÂ under a federal program called Operation Paperclip.Â
The program remains a controversial chapter in American history, when U.S. officials incorporated former Nazis into American life and institutions. Hereâ€™s how Operation Paperclip got off the ground.
In the spring of 1945, Allied forces were closing in on Nazi Germany, and the end of the war in Europe was in sight. Officials started to make pâ€¦

entry.title: 8 ways to find calm in Thailand's larger-than-life capital city
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Bangkok may have a reputation as one of the worldâ€™s biggest concrete jungles, but in between the neon-lit streets, rooftop bars and crowded markets there are some glorious pockets of calm. The cityâ€™s network of canals help create breathing space among the tuk-tuk packed neighbourhoods, and thereâ€™s a surprising amount of green space in the cityâ€™s environs â€” accessible by boat, bike or on foot. Here are eight of our favourite hideaways.Â
One of several plush hotels lining the Chao Phraya River, the Riva Arun is noteworthy for its peaceful, top-floor terrace restaurant, Above Riva. You can ease into the day with breakfast or settle in for sunset cocktails, watching boats crisscross the river. The dinner menu goes bâ€¦

ğŸ’¬ æ–‡ç« é‡‘å¥
The APIï¼Œ which has evolved through five preview iterationsï¼Œ aims to simplify and provide developers with clearerï¼Œ safer frameworks for managing parallel tasksï¼Œ particularly when working with virtual threads. Developers now open a scope through static factory methodsï¼Œ such as `StructuredTaskScope.open()`ï¼Œ a change that clarifies defaults and paves the way for richer completion policies. Each fork launches a subtaskï¼Œ by default on a virtual threadï¼Œ returning a `Subtask` handle whose `get()` is safe only after `join()` completes. ğŸ“Š æ–‡ç« ä¿¡æ¯

entry.title: Traveling during hurricane season? Here's what you should know
entry.summary:
Tropical cyclones are unpredictable so being prepared and knowing your options in case of a storm are key when travelling during hurricane season. From what to pack to whether travel insurance will cover you, hereâ€™s what you need to know about travelling during tropical cyclones.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Long balmy days, sparkling turquoise waters â€” these are the classic ingredients of a tropical break. But risk going during the hurricane season and you could end up looking at a very different picture. It doesnâ€™t necessarily mean trips have to be off the agenda though. In fact, for some, off-season prices and the lack of crowds make hurricane season a particularly attractive time to travel. Hereâ€™s how best to prepare.
Collectiveâ€¦

entry.title: Join a homegrown family feast in Italy's Basilicata region
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Deft and swift, she forms millimetre-thick sheets, slicing them into ribbons that she wraps around her narrow rolling pin to shape the screw-like ssÃ«ppondapÃ²rtÃ« (the word for â€˜door hinge pinâ€™ in local dialect) or cuts into the roughly square-shaped takkÃ«nuÃ¨ddÃ«. Next, the remaining dough â€” an egg-free mix of semolina flour and 00 pasta flour â€” is divided and rolled into thin sausages. She cuts these into one- and two-finger-width pieces and presses them into cavatelli and orecchiette, her digits moving in a blur of speed. Maria Coppola Colucci has been working in the kitchen at this pace for two hours and the septuagenarian grandmother shows no sign of flagging.
â€œWe were in the garden first thing this morning digginâ€¦

entry.title: Field of Dreams: Football Breathes Life into Yemenâ€™s Camps
entry.summary: Every summer in Maâ€™rib, Yemen, a place marked by loss and uncertainty, a football tournament offers a rare kind of hope. For hundreds of displaced youth living across more than a dozen sites, itâ€™s a chance to unite, to belong, and to dream.

entry.title: Try this budget alternative to Canada's famous Rocky Mountaineer
entry.summary:
Completed in 1914 as the western end of the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway, the Skeena travels through some of British Columbiaâ€™s wildest backcountry, including the 24,700sq mile Great Bear Rainforest, the largest temperate forest on Earth. Crossing vast tracts of British Columbian wilderness, the Skeena is one of Canadaâ€™s most thrilling, and little-known, rail journeys.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œLadies and gentlemen, weâ€™ll be making an unscheduled stop here to pick up another passenger,â€ announces train manager Alain Vermette. â€œIn fact, we need to back up. We just missed his stop.â€
Brakes squeal and gears grind as Via Rail Line 6 â€” better known as â€˜the Skeenaâ€™ â€” slows, shifts into reverse and trundles back down the track. A minute lâ€¦

entry.title: Where to see wildlife in Europe this summer
entry.summary:
Summer is the best time for wildlife-watching in Europe and spotting animals such as bears, wolves and lynx, is made possible thanks to knowledgable guides and various animal reintroduction schemes. From the FÄƒgÄƒraÈ™ Mountains of Romania to the teeming sea cliffs of St Kilda in Scotland, Europe is still home to staggering displays of summer wildlife. Whether youâ€™re searching for sperm whales, brown bears, dolphins or wolves, here are six of the best destinations to target.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Although quite densely populated, Europe isnâ€™t short of lonely island outposts, remote mountain ranges and dark, seemingly impenetrable forests â€” and many of them shelter world-class displays of animal activity. Youâ€™ll need to be well-equippedâ€¦

entry.title: Whatever happened to the samurai?
entry.summary:
The samurai, Japanâ€™s celebrated lineage of warriors, emerged in the Heian period (794-1185), when the rise of their status enabled them to mingle with the refined nobility living in the then-capital of Heian-kyÅ (Kyoto). Samurai fought in the ÅŒnin War and during the period of unrest that followed. From then on, the bushi, as the samurai were also called, made their mark on Japanese history with their exceptional fighting prowess, becoming emblematic of Japanese culture.
The high point of samurai history is often associated with the Tokugawa shogunate, also known as the Edo period (1603â€“1868), a time of peace, prosperity, isolationist policies, and cultural growth. This is the most studied era of Japanese history and the period in which novelists, filmmakers, and comic book creators teâ€¦

entry.title: This is the longest hiking trail in Central Asia
entry.summary:
Tourists prepare for a boating adventure on KÃ¶l-Suu (or Kel-Suu), a lake located in the heart of the Tian Shan mountain range in Kyrgyzstan. By summer's end, more than 600 miles will be added to the Kyrgyz Nomad Trail, granting hikers access to lesser-known parts of the country.
Adventurous hikers now have access to see a different side of Kyrgyzstan. TheÂ Kyrgyz Nomad TrailÂ (KNT) is a 1,243-mile (2,000-kilometer) long-distance hiking trail in northern and eastern Kyrgyzstan, which make it the longest trail network in Central Asia. Launched in June 2024, the KNTâ€”a network of 18 marked sectionsâ€”runs west to east passing through states (oblasts) such as Jalal-Abad, Naryn, and Issyk-Kul.
Along the trail, hikers also experienceÂ the beauty of KyrgyzstanÂ firsthand with natural landmaâ€¦
